metadata.subject: physics
metadata.topicName: Circular Motion in a Vertical Plane
metadata.dotPoint: investigate and apply theoretically Newton's second law to circular motion in a vertical plane (forces at the highest and lowest positions only)

net_force_toward_centre.name: Net Force Toward Centre
net_force_toward_centre.correct: In vertical circular motion, the net force (centripetal force) ALWAYS points toward the centre of the circle, regardless of position.

toward the ground.error: Gravity points down, but net force points to centre.
toward the ground.fix: Net force = centripetal force. At the bottom, centre is UP. At the top, centre is DOWN.
toward the ground.action: Draw circles. Mark centre. Net force arrow always points to that centre.

away from centre.error: That's the fictitious centrifugal force, not the real net force.
away from centre.fix: Real physics: net force is centripetal (toward centre).
away from centre.action: Analyse from an inertial frame. The real force is inward, not outward.

tangent to the circle.error: Tangent is the direction of velocity, not force.
tangent to the circle.fix: Velocity is tangential. Centripetal force is perpendicular to velocity.
tangent to the circle.action: Force perpendicular to velocity changes direction without changing speed.

in the direction of motion.error: That would speed up the object, not curve its path.
in the direction of motion.fix: Centripetal force is perpendicular to motion, causing direction change.
in the direction of motion.action: If force were along motion, the object would accelerate in a straight line.

persistent.gap: You don't understand centripetal force direction in vertical circles.
persistent.action: Draw 4 positions on a vertical circle. At each, draw the centre. Net force always points there.

forces_top_outside.name: Forces at Top (Outside Track)
forces_top_outside.correct: At the top of an outside track (like a hill): gravity points toward centre, normal points away. Centripetal = mg − N.

mv²/r = mg + N.error: Normal force points away from centre here, so it subtracts.
mv²/r = mg + N.fix: On a hill top: gravity is toward centre (+), normal is away (−). mv²/r = mg − N.
mv²/r = mg + N.action: Draw the FBD. Which forces point toward centre? Add those. Subtract the rest.

mv²/r = N − mg.error: Signs are swapped. Gravity dominates at the top of a hill.
mv²/r = N − mg.fix: At top of hill: mg toward centre, N away. Net = mg − N.
mv²/r = N − mg.action: Which is larger for slow speed? mg. So mg must be the positive term.

mv²/r = N + mg.error: This is for the bottom of a dip, not top of a hill.
mv²/r = N + mg.fix: At top outside: mv²/r = mg − N. At bottom: mv²/r = N − mg.
mv²/r = N + mg.action: Draw both cases. See which forces point toward centre in each.

N = mg always.error: N = mg only when stationary or in equilibrium, not in circular motion.
N = mg always.fix: In vertical circular motion, N varies with position and speed.
N = mg always.action: At top of hill: N < mg. At bottom of dip: N > mg.

persistent.gap: You're not correctly identifying force directions at the top of an outside curve.
persistent.action: Draw FBD at top of hill. Mark which forces point to centre. Those are positive for Fc.

forces_top_inside.name: Forces at Top (Inside Track/Loop)
forces_top_inside.correct: At the top inside a loop: both gravity AND normal/tension point toward centre (downward). Centripetal = mg + N.

mv²/r = mg − N.error: Both forces point the same direction here (toward centre).
mv²/r = mg − N.fix: Inside a loop at top: N points down (toward centre), mg points down. Both add.
mv²/r = mg − N.action: Draw a roller coaster at top of loop. Normal pushes toward centre.

mv²/r = N − mg.error: Both forces add, not subtract, at top of loop.
mv²/r = N − mg.fix: mv²/r = mg + N. Gravity and normal both point to centre at loop top.
mv²/r = N − mg.action: The track pushes you down into the loop. Gravity also pulls down.

N points upward at top of loop.error: Normal is perpendicular to surface, so it points toward loop centre.
N points upward at top of loop.fix: At top of loop, the track is above you, pushing down.
N points upward at top of loop.action: Imagine: the track 'floor' is now the ceiling. It pushes toward centre.

only gravity acts at top.error: Normal force acts too, unless speed is exactly v = √(gr).
only gravity acts at top.fix: Both mg and N act. Only when N = 0 does gravity alone provide centripetal.
only gravity acts at top.action: N = 0 is a special case (minimum speed). Usually N > 0 at top of loop.

persistent.gap: You're confusing force directions at the top of an inside loop.
persistent.action: Draw FBD at top of loop. Normal points from surface toward centre. Both forces add.

forces_bottom.name: Forces at Bottom of Circle
forces_bottom.correct: At the bottom: normal/tension points toward centre (up), gravity points away (down). Centripetal = N − mg.

mv²/r = N + mg.error: Gravity points away from centre at the bottom.
mv²/r = N + mg.fix: At bottom: N toward centre (+), mg away (−). Net = N − mg.
mv²/r = N + mg.action: Centre is UP at bottom. Gravity points DOWN (away from centre).

mv²/r = mg − N.error: N is toward centre, so it should be positive.
mv²/r = mg − N.fix: At bottom: N > mg for circular motion. N − mg = mv²/r.
mv²/r = mg − N.action: You feel heavier at bottom of dip. N must exceed mg.

mv²/r = mg + N.error: Forces oppose each other at bottom. One must subtract.
mv²/r = mg + N.fix: N points up (to centre), mg points down (away). Subtract.
mv²/r = mg + N.action: Draw the bottom of a loop. Centre is above. Which forces point up?

N = mg at bottom.error: N > mg at bottom because centripetal force is upward.
N = mg at bottom.fix: N = mg + mv²/r. Normal exceeds weight at bottom.
N = mg at bottom.action: You feel pressed into your seat at bottom of roller coaster. N > mg.

persistent.gap: You're not correctly setting up force equations at the bottom of a circle.
persistent.action: At bottom: centre is UP. N points up (+), mg points down (−). mv²/r = N − mg.

tension_vs_normal.name: Tension vs Normal Force
tension_vs_normal.correct: Tension (string) and normal force (track) play the same mathematical role in vertical circular motion equations.

tension only acts at top.error: Tension acts at all positions in string-based circular motion.
tension only acts at top.fix: Tension is present throughout. Its magnitude varies with position.
tension only acts at top.action: String is taut at all positions (unless speed is too low at top).

normal only acts at bottom.error: Normal acts wherever there's surface contact.
normal only acts at bottom.fix: On a track, normal force exists at every position the object contacts the track.
normal only acts at bottom.action: On a full loop, normal acts at top, bottom, and everywhere in between.

tension and normal are different forces.error: True, but mathematically they substitute for each other.
tension and normal are different forces.fix: In equations: T at top inside = N at top inside. Same math, different force.
tension and normal are different forces.action: String scenario: use T. Track scenario: use N. Same equation structure.

they always equal mg.error: Both vary with speed and position in circular motion.
they always equal mg.fix: At bottom: T or N > mg. At top: T or N can be < mg, = 0, or > mg.
they always equal mg.action: Calculate T at top and bottom for same speed. They differ.

persistent.gap: You're not recognizing when to use tension vs normal force.
persistent.action: String → tension. Track → normal. Same equations apply, just different symbols.

apparent_weight.name: Apparent Weight
apparent_weight.correct: Apparent weight is the normal force you feel. At bottom: heavier (N > mg). At top of outside curve: lighter (N < mg).

apparent weight = mg always.error: That's true weight, not apparent weight.
apparent weight = mg always.fix: True weight = mg (constant). Apparent weight = N (varies with motion).
apparent weight = mg always.action: Stand on scales in an elevator. Reading changes with acceleration.

heavier at top of loop.error: You feel lighter or weightless at top of a loop.
heavier at top of loop.fix: At top inside loop: N is small (or zero). You feel light.
heavier at top of loop.action: Roller coasters make you feel light at loop tops. That's low N.

lighter at bottom.error: You feel heavier at the bottom.
lighter at bottom.fix: At bottom: N > mg to provide upward centripetal force. Feels heavy.
lighter at bottom.action: At bottom of a dip, you're pressed into your seat. N is large.

weight and apparent weight are the same.error: They're equal only when there's no acceleration.
weight and apparent weight are the same.fix: Weight = mg (gravitational). Apparent weight = N (what you feel).
weight and apparent weight are the same.action: In free fall: mg acts but N = 0. You feel weightless.

persistent.gap: You're confusing true weight with apparent weight.
persistent.action: Weight = mg (never changes). Apparent weight = N (changes with acceleration).

zero_normal_formula.name: Zero Normal Force Speed
zero_normal_formula.correct: When N = 0 at the top of a circle, mv²/r = mg, giving v = √(gr). This is independent of mass.

v = gr.fix: From mv²/r = mg: v² = gr, so v = √(gr).
v = gr.action: Check units: √(m/s² × m) = √(m²/s²) = m/s. Correct for speed.

v = √(g/r).error: r should be in numerator under the root.
v = √(g/r).fix: v = √(gr). Larger radius means higher speed for zero normal.
v = √(g/r).action: Bigger loop needs faster entry speed for weightlessness at top.

v = √(mgr).error: Mass cancels out. It's not in the formula.
v = √(mgr).fix: From mv²/r = mg, m cancels: v² = gr, v = √(gr).
v = √(mgr).action: All masses feel weightless at same speed for given radius.

v = 2√(gr).action: Derive from mv²/r = mg with N = 0. No 2 appears.

persistent.gap: You haven't memorised the zero normal force formula.
persistent.action: Derive it: set N = 0 in mv²/r = mg + N (top inside). Solve for v.

minimum_speed_loop.name: Minimum Speed at Top of Loop
minimum_speed_loop.correct: For an object inside a loop (or on a string), v = √(gr) is the MINIMUM speed at the top to maintain contact/tension.

maximum speed.error: It's minimum for inside loops, maximum for outside curves.
maximum speed.fix: Inside loop: v_min = √(gr). Below this, you fall off. Outside hill: v_max = √(gr).
maximum speed.action: On a loop: go too slow at top → fall. On a hill: go too fast → leave road.

speed where tension is maximum.error: Tension is zero at this speed, not maximum.
speed where tension is maximum.fix: At v = √(gr), T = 0 at top. Go faster → T > 0.
speed where tension is maximum.action: Maximum tension is at the bottom of the circle, not the top.

speed at which object falls.error: At exactly this speed, object just maintains circular path.
speed at which object falls.fix: v = √(gr) is the threshold. Below it, object falls inward.
speed at which object falls.action: At v = √(gr): barely staying on track. Below: falls. Above: normal force helps.

applies to all positions.error: This formula applies specifically at the top of the circle.
applies to all positions.fix: v = √(gr) for N = 0 only applies at the top.
applies to all positions.action: At bottom, you can never have N = 0 while moving in a circle.

persistent.gap: You don't understand when v = √(gr) represents a minimum vs maximum.
persistent.action: Inside loop top: minimum (need enough speed to stay on). Outside hill: maximum (too fast lifts off).

maximum_speed_hill.name: Maximum Speed at Top of Hill
maximum_speed_hill.correct: For a vehicle on top of a hill (outside curve), v = √(gr) is the MAXIMUM speed before leaving the road.

minimum speed.error: On a hill, it's maximum. Below this, you stay on road.
minimum speed.fix: Hill: v_max = √(gr). Exceed this → leave the road.
minimum speed.action: Drive slowly over a bump: fine. Too fast: car becomes airborne.

speed where car accelerates upward.error: At this speed, normal force is zero. Above it, car leaves road.
speed where car accelerates upward.fix: At v = √(gr), N = 0. Faster means no contact with road.
speed where car accelerates upward.action: Car can't push down into the road harder than zero.

speed for maximum normal force.error: Normal force is zero at this speed, not maximum.
speed for maximum normal force.fix: N is maximum when stationary (N = mg). It decreases as speed increases on a hill.
speed for maximum normal force.action: Faster over hill → less normal force → eventually N = 0.

same as minimum for loop.error: The value is same (√(gr)), but meaning is opposite.
same as minimum for loop.fix: Loop: minimum speed. Hill: maximum speed. Same formula, different context.
same as minimum for loop.action: Context matters. Inside vs outside determines if it's min or max.

persistent.gap: You're not distinguishing inside loops from outside curves.
persistent.action: Inside (loop): v = √(gr) is minimum to stay on. Outside (hill): v = √(gr) is maximum before leaving.

weightlessness_vertical.name: Weightlessness in Vertical Circles
weightlessness_vertical.correct: You feel weightless when normal force is zero. Gravity still acts, but you're in free fall. This occurs at v = √(gr) at the top.

gravity is zero.error: Gravity is never zero. You feel weightless because N = 0.
gravity is zero.fix: Weight (mg) still acts. Apparent weight (N) is zero.
gravity is zero.action: Astronauts in orbit have g ≈ 9 m/s². They're in free fall, not zero gravity.

only in space.error: You can feel weightless on Earth too, in free fall.
only in space.fix: Any time N = 0 and you're falling freely, you feel weightless.
only in space.action: Top of a roller coaster loop: brief weightlessness. No space needed.

at the bottom of the circle.error: N is maximum at bottom, not zero.
at the bottom of the circle.fix: Weightlessness (N = 0) occurs at top, not bottom.
at the bottom of the circle.action: At bottom you feel heaviest. At top you can feel lightest.

when moving slowly.error: Weightlessness at top requires specific speed v = √(gr).
when moving slowly.fix: Too slow: you fall off (can't maintain circular path). Just right: N = 0.
when moving slowly.action: There's a precise speed for weightlessness. Not 'slow' or 'fast'—exact.

persistent.action: Weightless = N = 0 = free fall. Gravity still acts. You just don't feel it pushing back.

tension_at_bottom.name: Maximum Tension at Bottom
tension_at_bottom.correct: Tension is maximum at the bottom of a vertical circle because T must support weight AND provide upward centripetal force.

T = mg − mv²/r.error: Centripetal force adds to weight requirement at bottom.
T = mg − mv²/r.fix: T = mg + mv²/r at bottom. Both terms are positive.
T = mg − mv²/r.action: T must lift against gravity AND curve the path upward.

T is same everywhere.error: Tension varies with position in vertical circles.
T is same everywhere.fix: T is maximum at bottom, minimum at top.
T is same everywhere.action: Calculate T at top and bottom for same speed. Bottom is larger.

T = mv²/r only.error: You forgot to account for weight.
T = mv²/r only.fix: At bottom: T − mg = mv²/r, so T = mg + mv²/r.
T = mv²/r only.action: The string must overcome gravity AND provide centripetal force.

maximum at top.error: Tension is minimum at top, maximum at bottom.
maximum at top.fix: At top, gravity helps provide centripetal. At bottom, tension works alone.
maximum at top.action: Where is the string most likely to break? At the bottom (highest T).

persistent.gap: You don't understand why tension is greatest at the bottom.
persistent.action: At bottom: T alone provides mv²/r upward AND supports mg. T = mg + mv²/r.

string_breaking.name: String Breaking Condition
string_breaking.correct: A string breaks when tension exceeds its maximum rated tension. This is most likely at the bottom where T = mg + mv²/r is greatest.

breaks at top.error: Tension is lowest at the top, not highest.
breaks at top.fix: Maximum tension is at bottom. That's where breaking is most likely.
breaks at top.action: Calculate T_top and T_bottom. Which is larger?

breaks when T = 0.error: T = 0 means the string goes slack, not breaks.
breaks when T = 0.fix: T = 0 → string loose, object falls inward. Breaking needs high T.
breaks when T = 0.action: Slack string ≠ broken string. Breaking requires exceeding max T.

mass doesn't matter.error: Heavier mass means more tension needed.
mass doesn't matter.fix: T = mg + mv²/r. More mass → more tension.
mass doesn't matter.action: Swing a heavy vs light ball. Heavy one puts more tension on string.

speed doesn't matter.fix: T = mg + mv²/r. v² term dominates at high speed.
speed doesn't matter.action: Swing faster → more tension. Too fast → string breaks.

persistent.gap: You're not connecting tension calculations to string breaking.
persistent.action: Calculate T_bottom = mg + mv²/r. If T_bottom > T_max rated, string breaks.

forces_vertical.title: Forces in Vertical Circular Motion
forces_vertical.instructions: Complete the statements about forces in vertical circular motion.

sentences.text: In vertical circular motion, the net force (centripetal force) always points {{d1}}. This direction is the same whether the object is at the top, bottom, or sides of the circle.

d1.correct: toward the centre of the circle

sentences.text: At any position in vertical circular motion, the forces acting are {{d2}} and either normal force (on a track) or {{d3}} (on a string). These forces combine to produce the centripetal force.

d2.tooltip: What force always acts on objects near Earth?

d3.tooltip: What force does a string exert?

sentences.text: In the centripetal force equation, forces pointing toward the centre are {{d4}}, while forces pointing away from the centre are {{d5}}.

d4.tooltip: Forces toward centre contribute positively to Fc.

d5.tooltip: Forces away from centre oppose the centripetal requirement.

sentences.text: The centripetal force in vertical circular motion is provided by the {{d6}} of gravity and the normal (or tension) force, not by a separate 'centripetal force'.

d6.tooltip: Centripetal force is the net force, not an additional force.

top_circle.title: Forces at the Top of the Circle
top_circle.instructions: Complete the statements about forces at the top of vertical circles.

sentences.text: At the top of an inside loop (like a roller coaster), both gravity and normal force point {{d1}}. The equation is mv²/r = {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: The centre of the loop is below when you're at the top.

d2.tooltip: Both forces point to centre, so both add.

sentences.text: At the top of a hill (outside curve), gravity points {{d3}} and normal force points {{d4}}. The equation is mv²/r = mg − N.

d3.tooltip: Centre of the circular hill is below the car.

d4.tooltip: Normal force is perpendicular to surface, pushing up from road.

sentences.text: At the top of a vertical circle, the normal or tension force is at its {{d5}} value compared to other positions, assuming constant speed.

d5.tooltip: At top, gravity helps provide centripetal force.

bottom_circle.title: Forces at the Bottom of the Circle
bottom_circle.instructions: Complete the statements about forces at the bottom of vertical circles.

sentences.text: At the bottom of a vertical circle, the centre is {{d1}}. Normal force points {{d2}} and gravity points downward.

d1.tooltip: If you're at the bottom of a circle, the centre is up.

d2.tooltip: Surface pushes perpendicular to itself, which is up at bottom.

sentences.text: At the bottom, normal force must be {{d3}} than weight because it must provide the centripetal force {{d4}} supporting the weight.

d3.tooltip: N − mg = mv²/r, so N = mg + mv²/r > mg.

d4.tooltip: N does two jobs: support weight AND curve the path.

sentences.text: The equation at the bottom of a circle is mv²/r = {{d5}}. This is why you feel {{d6}} at the bottom of a roller coaster dip.

d5.tooltip: N toward centre, mg away. Net = N − mg.

sentences.text: At the bottom of a dip in the road, your car's normal force is {{d7}} your weight, which is why you feel pressed into your seat.

d7.tooltip: N = mg + mv²/r at bottom, so N > mg.

zero_normal.title: Zero Normal Force Condition
zero_normal.instructions: Complete the statements about the zero normal force condition.

sentences.text: When normal force equals zero at the top of a circle, gravity alone provides the centripetal force: mv²/r = {{d1}}.
The speed for zero normal force at the top is v = {{d2}}. This formula shows the speed is independent of {{d3}}.

d2.tooltip: From v² = gr, take the square root.

sentences.text: At v = √(gr), you feel {{d4}} because the normal force is zero. This is the same sensation as {{d5}}.

d4.tooltip: No normal force = no sensation of weight.

d5.tooltip: In free fall, you and your surroundings fall together.

forces_vertical.title: Applying Vertical Circular Motion Concepts
forces_vertical.instructions: Apply your understanding of vertical circular motion.

sentences.text: A ball on a string swung vertically has two forces: tension and gravity. At the top, both point {{d1}}, so Fc = T + mg. At the bottom, they point in {{d2}} directions, so Fc = T − mg.

d1.tooltip: Centre is below at the top. Both forces point down.

d2.tooltip: At bottom: T points up, mg points down.

sentences.text: For a roller coaster at the top of a loop, increasing the speed would {{d3}} the normal force. For a car on top of a hill, increasing speed would {{d4}} the normal force.

d3.tooltip: Inside loop: N = mv²/r − mg. More v² means more N.

d4.tooltip: Hill top: N = mg − mv²/r. More v² means less N.

sentences.text: The main difference between the equations at top of a loop versus top of a hill is that on a loop, normal force points {{d5}} the centre, while on a hill it points {{d6}} the centre.

d5.tooltip: Inside a loop, the track pushes you toward the centre.

d6.tooltip: On a hill, the road pushes you up, away from the centre below.

sentences.text: In all vertical circular motion scenarios, the {{d7}} always acts perpendicular to the surface of contact, whether that's a track, road, or the direction of a string.

d7.tooltip: Normal force is always perpendicular to surface.

top_circle.title: Analysing the Top of Vertical Circles
top_circle.instructions: Analyse scenarios at the top of vertical circles.

sentences.text: A 2 kg ball on a 0.5 m string at the top of a vertical circle at 4 m/s has centripetal force = {{d1}} N. If gravity provides 20 N downward, tension must be {{d2}} N.
For a ball on a string, if the speed at the top is exactly √(gr), the tension is {{d3}}. This is the {{d4}} speed to maintain circular motion.

d3.tooltip: At v = √(gr), gravity alone provides centripetal force.

d4.tooltip: Slower than this and the ball falls inward.

sentences.text: A 1000 kg car travels over a hill of radius 50 m. At 20 m/s, N = mg − mv²/r = 9800 − {{d5}} = {{d6}} N.

bottom_circle.title: Analysing the Bottom of Vertical Circles
bottom_circle.instructions: Analyse scenarios at the bottom of vertical circles.

sentences.text: At the bottom of a vertical circle, a 60 kg person on a roller coaster with r = 10 m at 15 m/s experiences N = mg + mv²/r = 588 + {{d1}} = {{d2}} N.
This person's apparent weight at the bottom is {{d3}} N, which is about {{d4}} times their normal weight of 588 N.
String tension is maximum at the bottom because tension must overcome {{d5}} AND provide {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: At bottom, gravity pulls down. String must counteract this.

d6.tooltip: Centre is above at bottom. Centripetal is upward.

zero_normal.title: Applying Zero Normal Force Concepts
zero_normal.instructions: Apply the zero normal force condition to various scenarios.

sentences.text: For a loop of radius 20 m, the minimum speed at the top is v = √(gr) = √({{d1}}) = {{d2}} m/s.
For a car on a hill of radius 40 m, the maximum speed to stay on the road is v = √(gr) = {{d3}} m/s. Above this speed, the car would {{d4}}.

d4.tooltip: Normal force can't go negative. Car loses contact.

sentences.text: The zero normal force speed v = √(gr) is the same numerical value for both loops and hills of equal radius, but it represents a {{d5}} for loops and a {{d6}} for hills.

d5.tooltip: Inside loop: need at least this to stay on track.

d6.tooltip: Hill: exceed this and you become airborne.

forces_vertical.title: Mastering Vertical Circular Motion
forces_vertical.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of vertical circular motion.

sentences.text: A common error is thinking centrifugal force pushes outward. In reality, {{d1}} is the real force, and the outward sensation is due to your body's {{d2}} resisting the inward acceleration.

d1.tooltip: Centripetal is the real force; centrifugal is fictitious.

d2.tooltip: Your body wants to continue straight. That's inertia.

sentences.text: The reason N varies with position in vertical circles is that gravity's contribution to centripetal force changes. At the top of a loop, gravity {{d3}} centripetal motion. At the bottom, gravity {{d4}} it.

d3.tooltip: At loop top, both gravity and N point to centre.

d4.tooltip: At bottom, gravity points away from centre (down).

sentences.text: Roller coasters use {{d5}} loops rather than circular loops because this design allows a {{d6}} entry speed while maintaining positive normal force throughout.

d5.tooltip: Smaller radius at top means lower speed still works.

d6.tooltip: Smaller r at top: v = √(gr) is smaller.

top_circle.title: Mastering Top of Circle Analysis
top_circle.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of force analysis at the top of vertical circles.

sentences.text: For an object inside a loop: at low speed N is {{d1}}, at v = √(gr) N is {{d2}}, at high speed N is large and points downward.

d1.tooltip: Too slow: can't maintain contact. Falls inward.

sentences.text: Zero-gravity flights achieve weightlessness by flying in a parabolic arc where the aircraft is essentially in {{d3}}. At the top of the arc, passengers experience N = {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: The plane follows a trajectory where only gravity acts.

d4.tooltip: Floor doesn't push on passengers. They float.

sentences.text: A key insight: at the top of a hill, normal force N = mg − mv²/r. For N to be positive, speed must satisfy v < {{d5}}. For N = 0, v = {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: N = mg − mv²/r > 0 requires mv²/r < mg.

bottom_circle.title: Mastering Bottom of Circle Analysis
bottom_circle.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of force analysis at the bottom of vertical circles.

sentences.text: If a string has maximum tension T_max and the ball has mass m at radius r, the maximum speed at the bottom is found from T_max = mg + mv²/r, giving v = {{d1}}.

d1.tooltip: Rearrange: mv² = r(T_max − mg), v² = r(T_max − mg)/m.

sentences.text: A 0.5 kg ball on a 1 m string with breaking tension 100 N can be swung at maximum bottom speed v where 100 = 5 + 0.5v²/1. Solving: v² = {{d2}}, so v = {{d3}} m/s.
The feeling of being 'pressed into your seat' at the bottom of a roller coaster is due to the {{d4}} normal force. This is {{d5}} the situation at the top of a loop.

d4.tooltip: N = mg + mv²/r at bottom. Both terms add.

d5.tooltip: At top: feel light. At bottom: feel heavy.

zero_normal.title: Mastering Weightlessness and Critical Speeds
zero_normal.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of zero normal force conditions.

sentences.text: The sensation of weightlessness occurs when N = 0, but gravity {{d1}} acting. The misconception of 'zero gravity' should be replaced with 'zero {{d2}}'.

d1.tooltip: Gravity never stops. You just don't feel the floor pushing back.

d2.tooltip: Apparent weight = N. When N = 0, you feel weightless.

sentences.text: Summary: For inside loops, v = √(gr) is {{d3}} speed. For outside curves (hills), v = √(gr) is {{d4}} speed. Both give N = 0 at the top.

d3.tooltip: Below this on a loop: fall off. Above: N > 0.

d4.tooltip: Above this on a hill: leave the road. Below: N > 0.

sentences.text: A pilot doing a vertical loop feels the greatest force at the {{d5}} of the loop. If the loop radius is too small or speed too high, the pilot can experience forces exceeding {{d6}}, risking blackout.

d5.tooltip: N is maximum at bottom: N = mg + mv²/r.

d6.tooltip: High-g maneuvers can cause N >> mg.

sentences.text: Both the minimum speed for a loop and maximum speed for a hill equal √(gr), demonstrating that this critical speed depends on {{d7}} and {{d8}}, not on the object's mass.

d7.tooltip: g appears in the formula v = √(gr).

d8.tooltip: r appears in the formula v = √(gr).
